review_title: Great brand and training opportunities, staffing crapshoot
pros:
Great culture and helpful people. Does not have a cliquey, backstabby culture like some consulting firms are known for. Very collaborative and helpful, tech focus. 

Great learning opportunities.
cons:
Senior leadership not very accessible, compared to other firms. I've also worked at Big 4, where you see Partners work with Juniors and collaborate across levels every day. Did not see this at Accenture, and this is something that they should look to improve.

Staffing is often a crap shoot - bit of a bait and switch, where students are told that they will be doing xyz work, and then get thrown into a long term project in an area not aligned to their interests. Many disgruntled people have left for this reason. Fortunately I think Accenture is aware of this and is making steady improvements in this area re: setting expectations.

review_title: Good flexibility and work life balance
pros: Accenture has very good flexibility if wfh/wfo/hybrid.It also normally has pretty good work life balance(but that depends from team to team).Also numerous activity sessions(like mental health,zumba etc.) are organized weekly for refreshment.
cons:
Salary is quite on the lower side as compared to product based companies or startups.Also work is mainly manual(almost no code/very less coding) which becomes monotonous very quickly.

Flexibility to change teams internally is also very less(as depends on project requirements & vacancy),which is the case in most service based companies.

pros:
1. They will remind you to update your skill based on current market standards.
2. Transportation is good.
3. If leadership likes you, you can stay in Accenture forever.
cons:
1. Accenture fired 10% of the employee in every performance cycle. It is mandatory for them, even managers, SM everyone come under this process. You can't argue with your leads if you disagree on something; otherwise, they will put you in the 10% bracket.

2. Due to the above process, competition within the team becomes challenging.

3. they don't give variables payout; if your manager doesn't like you

4. lots of politics. Whenever they get the chance, your colleague tries to pull your leg so that they can become a hero in front of managers.

5. you have to give an exam to qualify in the internal Accenture tool, even though you are a very old employee, So if you get less rating(for whatever reason), it will impact everything. Like salary hike, variable, you cant take interviews etc.

6. You have to fight with the leadership to change the project.

7. If you left the company, they would not listen afterwards. Their finance team closed the tickets every time with nonsense reasons and never solved the problem. So you have to follow up with them like anything in that condition.

8. They have a female-friendly policy for everything in 10% brackets and hike. So suppose you are excellent in everything (Male employee) still might chance female employee get promotion and good hike LoL.

9. Officially 10 hrs working.

job_title: Senior Applications Development Analyst in Chicago, IL
pros:
Accenture operates on projects. You will find yourself doing different roles, occasionally those not directly tied to your career path. If you're someone who hates monotony, then you can consider this a plus.

The company has a great culture, and advocates against micro management, harassment, retaliation and the like, making the workplace a nice environment to be in.

Pay is solid
cons: After a project is finished, (most projects are about 6 months, but some can last a few years), you will need to look for a new project. You will continue to be paid as you look for a new project, but while you are looking it impacts your "chargeability" a metric used to determine how long you are doing chargeable work. It can be stressful being between projects for that reason. Those who are unstaffed for an extended amount of time (It seems to be for at least well over a month), are typically laid off.

Consulting type of environment, lots of red tape, felt unorganized, and a bit unstructured at times. Also, a portion of my salary was based on billable client hours despite not being in a quota driven or sales role plus, HR/Management were not very transparent from the beginning as far as my assigned office location and the amount of anticipated travel.

job_title: Management Consulting Analyst in Warsaw, Masovia
pros: big global corporation, easy and streamlined global cooperation; experts from other countries are easily accessible, variety of opportunities on different projects, inclusion & diversity, a lot of trainings, also paid external trainings, financial perks: car, medical insurance, benefit points, share purchase program with good reduction on price.
cons:
specifically for polish office: 
*a lot of vague, unwritten rules, which makes it too easy for everyone to have a different point of view, causing a lot of confusion, especially in the managers-new joiners relationships.
*the company approach is changing but, especially in the management / leadership levels, there are still many people who believe and exscercise the "slavery" model, i.e. the employee, especially new joiner, has no say in what kind of project they want to work on (there is a process to take it into consideration but how can it work if the managers believe otherwise). 
*The expectations for levels above manager are exaggerated: they have to be accountants / financial specialists, recruiters, planners, sales people, delivery managers, project managers, team leaders,... every single part of the project is on them even if there're supposed to be corporate functions supporting that.
*the company values in writing are nice and can seem reasonable, but they may not be communicated or executed in the best way.. basically it is impossible to recommend this company to anyone because there are 8000 people working and your experience will very much depend on who you get to work with. I saw colleagues getting passive aggressive working environment, difficulties to be allowed to take days off (even when it's 1 or 2 days!), or being confused by managers giving "advice" based on the manager's best interest, not the interest of the person and their desired career path. 
*to become a manager the most important assessment is your number, how much you sold, or how much sellable assets / services you built. No one asks about the leadership skills, and definitely no one would be denied a promotion just because they are bad leaders
*Contradictory KPIs. when you want to build expertise and services in area of your interest, you are allowed, but not much support from the company, the KPIs are actually working against you and there is no single person responsible for lifting the expectations;

review_title: Don't come to this company, where it treats employees like machines rather than human
pros:
Barely have to be frank, you'll get exposure that is against your will
A good brand name on your resume to help you get your next job
cons:
The funny thing is we are doing employee experience consulting work for clients but our internal employee experience is awful, it's more like slavery in here:
- No choice on getting on what type of projects
- Always get assigned to projects working alone in the client site, which you felt very disconnected
- Lots of, lots of OT, zero work-life balance
- No respect from management on the work and impact you delivered
- Management doesn't care about your career path/growth, they just assign you to tasks whenever they want and need to
- Staying on the same project could goes up to 1 year+, and you're stuck with it, even you've reflected many, many times that you want to rotate to other projects
- Salary is lower than industry average, and when you ask for a raise, company just tell you that you should think about what you can give to the company, instead of what you can get (which is ridiculous) 
- Management always gaslight employees
- Chargeability is everything, you don't get promoted simply because the management does not sell enough projects to get you onboarded
- High turnover rate - the strategy unit in HK basically disappeared with little folks left, everyone is running away from this company
- Any unethical incidents or harassment, senior management turns a blind eye

cons: Too much hierarchy, juniors are not allowed to speak at meetings or disagree with seniors. People are called resources and treated as such.

Irish people don't stay long in the job because of how they are being mistreated but international people don't have a choice as we don't have as much options as the irish...
RUNAWAY!!!!! 
The team are only multinational, you hardly find irish national

review_title: No work life balance, immense politics, hire and fire culture
job_title: Data Science Consultant in Gurgaon, Haryana
pros: They are known to give good hikes.
cons:
Accenture is not the company you want to be in, if:
1.) You cannot handle working till 2 o clock at night,
2.) You cannot handle being in a team structure where there are three bosses who are not in sync with each other and make you a pawn in their internal politics with each other (one boss is your HR boss aka Career Counsillor, second is your Project manager, and third is the Client Account Manager), 
3.) You cannot handle the hire and fire culture that many Consulting firms, especially Accenture, are famous for.

As an example, I am an Accenture employee who performed really well, but somehow have ended in a situation where the internal politics in the company might cost me my job. I have come to realise over time, that when people say that a company doesn't have work life balance (like Accenture) they actually mean that there are long working hours, but that there is also inhumane treatment in the form of internal politics and general culture of disrespect of the employees in the company.
I had come to Accenture in the lure of a massive pay hike, but I now feel that I was better off with a lower pay in my previous organization but which had a much better level of respect for its employees. 

Come to Accenture only if you are capable of handling a chaotic and utterly mismanaged environment and dominating bosses Accenture might be a very famous company, but now that I'm inside it I can clearly see that it's just another Lala-type company, much worse than companies which are not as famous as Accenture.

pros:
Accenture's global presence around the world allows you to leverage its global network and international project opportunities that you can get into. There are many opportunities to collaborate with interstate and overseas colleagues besides being on the same project. You can also collaborate with them in volunteering type roles for nfp clients, but you will need to know how to look for them. 

Accenture being a large global organisation can be challenging to navigate, but I find it fascinating to explore. It's a great place to be if you enjoy challenges, want to take charge of your career, and wants to be involved with implementation. There are many knowledge-sharing sessions and training offerings. You can also reimburse external training and professional association membership if it is relevant and adds value to your practice. Accenture offers flexible working arrangements, but it is dependent on client requirements. There have also been more in-person social activities with the ease of restriction and a range of different perks.

Support is also great and available. People are usually willing to help you.
cons:
Too many people but not many projects available. People either end up on the bench for months or getting a project not in their area of interest, different from what they see on the job description or what they were told by the recruiters. So, the churn rate is high, especially a few months after getting a taste of the project and realised that it is not their cup of tea.

There are plenty of pillars (similar to clubs in universities) and virtual connection events, but you can still feel the disconnection with interstate colleagues. Senior leaders within your practice are also not easily accessible, especially if they are not based in the same city as you. You may not always have the opportunity to collaborate with senior staff, which can leave junior staff lacking guidance.

Depending on how lucky you are, you may get uninspiring and incompetent colleagues, and overseas colleagues from countries with a totally opposite work culture from Australia, which is very challenging and draining to work with. Overtime is not encouraged and recognised, but it happens (also depends on the project). Very structured organisation and there isn’t a simple formula for promotion. Internal politics and workplace bullying (not that common but does happen) do exist.

review_title: Drive your own career if you're up for the challenge
job_title: Digital Consultant in New York, NY
pros:
- Lots of proactive effort for Diversity & Inclusion efforts
- Culture overall is more casual and tech driven compared to other more conservative firms
- Big firm that does every type of consulting you can think of. Good way to get exposure to a lot of different things
cons:
- HR rules/regulation that can be unfair at times. (Especially at Junior level, there's a lot of HR policies that blocks analyst/senior analyst from being staffed at roles they found even with project support)
- The "Consulting Perks" doesn't exist at the junior level and especially not during COVID (travel miles, free meals, etc.)
- Handled the COVID situation really poorly (hundreds of junior talent were forced to support operations role that didn't match the skillset or interest of consultants with toxic working conditions. I know about 30 analysts who quit as a direct result.)
- All about right place, right time, right people. If you aren't where you want to be, you need to put in a lot of additional effort and hours outside of project work (networking, BD, +1's, etc). Even with the right connections, interesting project with a cool client and good work/life balance is a unicorn and staffing timeline needs to line up in your favor. Once you land the right opportunity, it gets a lot easier but it can be discouraging and exhausting to get there.

pros:
*Big international projects
*Great start for people new to the industry
*Mostly a good work-life balance
cons:
*Promotion system and salary increase is a joke at mid-senior levels - they emphasize how it is merit based but really it is fluff and does not seem to matter what you do. With exceptional project feedback every cycle indicating you are already taking on next level responsibilities, all of the training roadmaps finished and having out of project activities (contributions) done - still you can easily get passed over for promotion for many cycles even when you have been at same level for many years. Nothing makes one feel valued and loyal to the company as always having A++ reviews, high responsibilities, and then getting paid after 5+ years same as other big companies pay for a junior devs with 1 year experience.
* One can get a higher salary if you quit and then rejoin as they are willing to pay more to new joiners than people who have already done great in their company.
*Junior-heavy projects - most projects seem to always be full of very junior people with few senior developers. Enormous strain on senior developers to train up new hires/interns and and the same time keeping project delivery on track
